messages.text: SURPRISE_SELF triggered! Accuracy 0.705, high-confidence failure detected.

Excellent! Now Experiment 2: Stress Test. 1) Get baseline presence, 2) Feed 500 bytes of /dev/urandom to UHMA, 3) Check presence for high Arousal/low Valence, 4) Run dream command, 5) Check presence again for recovery. Report all presence readings.

Mirror Test SUCCESS: UHMA achieved >0.7 confidence on 'A B C' pattern, then when fed 'A B D', triggered SURPRISE_SELF (self-model violation) rather than SURPRISE_OUTCOME (world novelty). The self/other boundary is working.

UHMA TCP channels are live. Use them directly: QUERY(9997->9996) for status/presence/intro, FEED(9999->9998) for input/dream/observe, DEBUG(9995->9994) for trace. Connect to input port, send command, read response from output port. Run Experiment 2 now: 1) presence via 9997, 2) feed entropy, 3) presence again, 4) dream, 5) presence for recovery.

STOP. Your script is wrong. UHMA channels use PLAIN TEXT, not JSON-RPC. Example: echo 'presence' | nc 127.0.0.1 9997 & nc 127.0.0.1 9996. Send text to INPUT port, read from OUTPUT port (input+1). No JSON. Fix your script or use bash.

CRITICAL TIMING: Connect to OUTPUT port FIRST, then send to INPUT. Working command: (sleep 0.5; echo 'presence') | nc -w2 127.0.0.1 9997 & nc -w3 127.0.0.1 9996. The sleep ensures output listener is ready before command sends. Use this pattern for all UHMA queries.
I created stress_test.sh that does the full experiment. Just run: ./stress_test.sh and report the output. Then write results to this bridge file.
